literaryDevices.name: Metaphor
literaryDevices.description: A figure of speech that makes a comparison between two unrelated things by stating one thing is another.

literaryDevices.name: Simile
literaryDevices.description: A figure of speech that compares two different things using the words 'like' or 'as'.
literaryDevices.example: Her cheeks are red like a rose.

literaryDevices.name: Alliteration
literaryDevices.description: The repetition of the same consonant sounds at the beginning of words that are in close proximity.
literaryDevices.example: Peter Piper picked a peck of pickled peppers.

literaryDevices.name: Personification
literaryDevices.description: A form of figurative language in which non-human objects are given human characteristics.
literaryDevices.example: The wind whispered through the trees.

literaryDevices.name: Onomatopoeia
literaryDevices.description: A word that imitates the natural sounds of a thing. It creates a sound effect that mimics the thing described.

literaryDevices.name: Hyperbole
literaryDevices.description: An exaggerated statement or claim not meant to be taken literally.
literaryDevices.example: I'm so hungry I could eat a horse.

literaryDevices.name: Irony
literaryDevices.description: A contrast or incongruity between expectations for a situation and what is reality.

literaryDevices.name: Oxymoron
literaryDevices.description: A figure of speech in which two opposite ideas are joined to create an effect.

literaryDevices.name: Anaphora
literaryDevices.description: The deliberate repetition of the first part of the sentence in order to achieve an artistic effect.
literaryDevices.example: Every day, every night, in every way, I am getting better and better.

literaryDevices.name: Euphemism
literaryDevices.description: A polite, indirect expression that replaces words and phrases considered harsh and impolite, or which suggest something unpleasant.

literaryDevices.name: Assonance
literaryDevices.description: The repetition of vowel sounds in nearby words. It is used to reinforce the meanings of words or to set the mood.

literaryDevices.name: Consonance
literaryDevices.description: The repetitive sounds produced by consonants within a sentence or phrase.
literaryDevices.example: The ship has sailed to the far off shores.

literaryDevices.name: Symbolism
literaryDevices.description: The use of symbols to signify ideas and qualities, by giving them symbolic meanings that are different from their literal sense.
literaryDevices.example: A chain can symbolize the coming together of two things.
